awd_titl_txt: Regulating Nitric Oxide Homeostasis and its Impact on Plant Growth and Reproduction
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will determine how nitric oxide (NO) modulates important aspects of plant growth, development and seed yield, processes critical to food security and plant biomass production. NO acts as a signaling molecule in all higher organisms, and the discoverers of the role of NO in cells were awarded the Nobel Prize. This project will use biochemical and genetic approaches in Arabidopsis thaliana to investigate how a specific protein enzyme, known as GSNOR, controls the amount and effects of NO in plants. Results will contribute to our overall understanding of the mechanism of NO action in all organisms. One postdoctoral researcher, a graduate student, two undergraduates and a middle school teacher will receive training in laboratory research, as well as mentoring in written and oral communication of scientific data for specialist and lay audiences. In addition, outreach programs will focus on engaging teachers and students in Amherst middle and high schools with the goals of developing hands on experiments for middle school students involving plant materials and exposing high school students to University of Massachusetts STEM undergraduate majors and their campus experiences. The engagement with Amherst schools will also serve the important goal of strengthening community ties with the university.

Despite the clear involvement of nitric oxide (NO) in multiple plant processes, including germination, root growth and fertility, a basic understanding of the mechanisms by which NO exerts its effects on systems critical for plant growth and development is lacking and will be addressed in this project. The cellular signaling and regulatory effects of NO are mediated by reversible, posttranslational protein redox modifications, including cysteine (Cys) nitrosation (Cys-SNO) and glutathionylation (Cys-SG). These reversible, covalent modifications result primarily from reaction with S-nitrosoglutathione (GSNO), a soluble NO-adduct of the abundant cellular redox buffer glutathione. They can have major effects on protein activity, indicating there must be mechanisms to control NO and GSNO concentrations in both time and space within cells. This project investigates how the enzyme S-nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR) plays a major role in modulating GSNO and protein nitrosation levels. A model for regulation of GSNOR activity by nitrosation of specific Cys residues has been developed from biochemical studies of Arabidopsis, yeast and human GSNOR. This project will test this model both in vitro (Aim 1) and in vivo in Arabidopsis thaliana (Aim 2) using biochemistry and genetics, and possible regulation of GSNOR activity by other posttranslational modifications will be investigated. Experiments will also determine how GSNOR nitrosation is reversed by specific cytosolic redox proteins in the thioredoxin and thioredoxin reductase families (Aims 1 and 2). Results will develop a complete picture of the possible redox modifications controlling GSNOR activity and thereby cellular NO levels, and provide novel data on the activity and specificity of cytosolic thioredoxins. Finally, changes in protein nitrosation associated with the reduced fertility of Arabidopsis GSNOR null mutants will be determined by novel mass spectrometry methods (Aim 3). In total, experiments address how mechanisms controlling activity of a single enzyme (GSNOR) are propagated to result in phenotypic changes at the whole organism level.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The small, gaseous molecule nitric oxide (NO) acts in signaling pathways to control many physiological and developmental processes in both animals and plants. The importance of NO was recognized with the award of the Noble Prize in 1998 to the discoverers of its signaling properties. In cells, NO is stabilized by attachment to glutathione, an ubiquitous antioxidant, to form S-nitrosoglutathione (GSNO). The available GSNO and consequently the available NO is controlled in part by the enzyme S-nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR) which reduces NO using NADH. To understand what processes require NO and what other cellular components control NO signaling, this project investigated Arabidopsis thaliana plants that have disrupted control of NO levels due to mutation of the GSNOR enzyme. Experiments uncovered a major role for GSNOR and NO in plant fertility. A significant percentage of female gametes fail to develop sufficiently to be fertilized, reducing seed yield. Results show correct female development relies on expression of GSNOR in parental tissues, which in turn impacts delivery of the plant hormone auxin. Importantly, increased expression of GSNOR in parental tissues or delivery of auxin could rescue the fertility defect and, additionally, could improve seed yield under salt and drought conditions. Further understanding of this aspect of fertility control could contribute to mediating crop yield loss under adverse conditions.  

Analysis of changes in the protein components of GSNOR deficient plants resulted in discovery of a large increase of four, highly similar aldo-keto reductase enzymes. These enzymes were found to also reduce GSNOR (using NADPH), representing a previously unrecognized mechanism for controlling NO levels in plants. Single mutants of all four enzymes have been generated, and plants containing mutations in more than one gene will be used to understand the importance of these enzymes in controlling NO levels and  in mediating plant growth and development.

Based on the hypothesis that GSNOR activity (and therefore NO signaling) is likely regulated in part by interaction with other proteins, experiments were performed to identify GSNOR-interacting proteins using a labeling technique in intact plants.  Nineteen proteins were identified, and six of these, along with other potential interactors previously identified in the literature were further tested for interaction in plant leaves. Results indicate that eight proteins connected to redox regulation interact with GSNOR, potentially being involved in controlling GSNOR activity and NO levels. Determining how these interactions change GSNOR activity is a critical area for further research in the area of NO signaling in plants.

Because signaling by NO is mediated to a large extent by NO modification of cysteine amino acids in proteins, GSNOR mutant plants were also investigated for changes in formation of NO-modified proteins. A novel method for identifying these proteins was employed for the first time in plants and uncovered over 500 previously undetected NO-modified proteins in floral tissues. How these modifications contribute to plant development remains to be discovered.

This project contributed to education and training at multiple levels. Support for curriculum development was provided over two full summers for two middle school teachers; a one day STEM workshop for 12 high school teachers provided insight into protein and DNA manipulation in plants; three teachers spent five summer days performing advanced lab research to enhance their knowledge and curriculum; and supplies and protocols were provided to enable local high school classes to perform polymerase chain reaction experiments serving over 100 students every year for 4 years. The award supported four women undergraduate researchers, three of whom have graduated and completed Honors Research Theses. All students presented their results at university sponsored conferences, two attended national conferences of major scientific societies, and one spent two weeks in Italy training with a collaborator. Of the three who have graduated, one will begin medical school, another is employed in the biotech industry, and the third has started a PhD program. The award also supported one postdoctoral researcher who attended multiple national and international meetings, as well as professional training courses for analysis of mass spectrometry data.

In summary, this research has defined the importance of regulated NO to plant fertility and seed yield, discovered new enzymes involved in NO metabolism and identified new proteins that potentially regulate and are regulated by NO levels. Training has enhanced the STEM workforce and augmented STEM curriculum in local schools. Results have been published in high impact peer reviewed journals and been presented at multiple national and international venues.
